author: @dolodestinations7628

author: @lukemoon4466
text: If you are getting 'not all arguments converted during string formatting'..............this is likely down to not including a trailing comma when feeding in instances of 'thwart()' to the tuple. Even if only one value is fed in (in this case 'thwart(username)') you need to use a trailing comma in the tuple that encases the 'thwart' calls...............note the comma comes immediately after the parentheses of 'thwart'.        x = c.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = (%s)",                           (thwart(username),))"

author: @kevinhollis1143
text: The original confusion over the x variable being an int and then changing it to its length attribute was the fact if you had put "SELECT count(*) FROM USERS......." this would have returned you the number of rows for your where clause....

author: @446nandan
text: +sentdex Hey Harrison thanks for the tutorials, they are awesome and extremely useful. I had a problem getting to run the x = c.execute part from you script, I'm assuming it's because of different version of a module. I'm posting it here so if any body runs into the same problem can use this code.   Problem: x = c.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username IN (%s)",(thwart(username)))  Fix: x = c.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username IN (%s)",[(thwart(username))])
